sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To investigate how parental resilience affects children’s health-related quality of life (QoL) following hospital discharge, comparing outcomes between paediatric intensive care and general ward admissions.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: Prospective cohort study with 2-month follow-up.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Tertiary care hospital in Thailand (February 2021–August 2022).

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: 100 parent–child dyads (58 paediatric intensive care unit (PICU), 42 general ward) with children aged 4–16 years; 95% completed both assessments.

sec.title: Main outcome measures
sec.p: Parental resilience assessed using the Resilience Quotient questionnaire and children’s QoL measured using the Paediatric QoL Inventory 4.0.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Cross-lagged analysis revealed that baseline parental resilience significantly predicted child QoL at follow-up (β=0.426, p=0.038), but baseline child QoL did not significantly predict changes in parental resilience. Hierarchical regression identified changes in parental resilience (β=1.090, p<0.01) and baseline child QoL (β=0.524, p<0.01) as key predictors of later QoL. Parents of general ward patients showed greater improvements in resilience and their children demonstrated significant improvements in social functioning (21.67 vs 8.58 points, p=0.005) and total QoL scores (12.06 vs 4.13 points, p=0.038) compared with the PICU group.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Parental resilience is a significant predictor of children’s QoL following hospital discharge, with a unidirectional relationship where parental resilience influences subsequent child outcomes. This association persisted after controlling for demographic and clinical factors, suggesting the potential importance of psychological support for parents during their child’s hospitalisation regardless of care setting. Longitudinal studies with longer follow-up periods are needed to validate these findings and assess their clinical significance.

sec.title: WHAT IS ALREADY KNOWN ON THIS TOPIC

list-item.p: Hospitalisation can be traumatic for both children and parents, often causing lasting psychological effects. Parental psychological distress has been linked to adverse child health outcomes following hospitalisation, but the specific relationship between parental resilience and child quality of life has remained underexplored, particularly in non-Western healthcare settings.

This study identifies that parental resilience independently predicts children’s quality of life following hospital discharge in both paediatric intensive care unit (PICU) and general ward settings, with a unidirectional relationship in which initial parental resilience influences subsequent child outcomes but not the reverse. While the overall pattern of recovery was similar across groups, modest differences in specific quality of life domains were observed between PICU and ward cohorts.

sec.title: HOW THIS STUDY MIGHT AFFECT RESEARCH, PRACTICE OR POLICY

list-item.p: While this observational study does not establish causality, the findings suggest that caregiver psychological functioning may play a role in child recovery following hospitalisation. This highlights a potential target for future research. Longitudinal studies and intervention trials are needed to evaluate whether supporting parental resilience—particularly during the hospital-to-home transition—can improve child outcomes. These findings may ultimately inform family-centred care models and postdischarge support strategies.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hospitalisation in a paediatric intensive care unit (PICU) can profoundly impact the well-being of both children and their families. The PICU represents a critical aspect of global healthcare, with approximately 13% of paediatric hospital admissions in the USA requiring intensive care.1 While survival rates in modern PICUs have significantly improved,2 the focus has shifted towards understanding and optimising long-term health-related quality of life (QoL) for both children and their families.3 4

Despite its vital role in saving lives, the PICU environment exposes children to multiple stressors, including separation from parents, loss of control and exposure to severe illness.5 6 These stressors, coupled with invasive procedures and complex medical equipment, create an overwhelming experience for both children and their caregivers.7 8 This constellation of impairments, collectively termed postintensive care syndrome in paediatrics (PICS-p), has emerged as a conceptual framework describing these new or worsening physical, cognitive, emotional and social health impairments in children following critical illness.911

The PICS-p framework recognises the interconnected nature of child and family outcomes, highlighting the importance of parental psychological well-being in children’s recovery trajectories.12 The PICS-p model emphasises that critical illness affects not just the child but the entire family system, making parental resilience particularly relevant to understanding recovery outcomes.5

Parents, in particular, struggle with uncertainty regarding their child’s prognosis, the need to navigate an unfamiliar medical environment and the psychological burden associated with critical illness. Studies have shown that parents—especially those experiencing unplanned PICU admissions—may develop post-traumatic stress symptoms (PTSS) or disorders,12 as well as other PICS-p-related symptoms.13 Notably, mothers are nearly twice as likely as fathers to receive a new mental health diagnosis following their child’s PICU admission.14

The psychological, physical and social impact of a child’s critical illness extends well beyond the hospital stay, sometimes persisting for years after discharge.5 15 16 However, responses to PICU-related stress vary widely. While some families experience significant distress, others demonstrate resilience, adapting effectively to the traumatic experience.6

Resilience—the ability to maintain psychological well-being after experiencing stressful situations— has emerged as a crucial factor in how parents cope with their child’s hospitalisation and its aftermath.15 17 18 Higher parental resilience has been associated with fewer symptoms of anxiety, depression and post-traumatic stress after PICU discharge. A previous study found that 46% of parents recover from post-traumatic stress within a year following their child’s intensive care discharge.19 Therefore, assessing parental resilience may be a valuable approach to identifying those at greater risk for psychological distress post-PICU.20

While most PICS-p research has focused on Western populations,9 10 21 there is growing recognition of the need to understand these phenomena in diverse cultural contexts. Family dynamics, cultural values and healthcare systems vary significantly across different regions, potentially influencing both resilience patterns and QoL outcomes.22 Although prior research has established the importance of parental mental health in child outcomes, the direct impact of parental resilience on children’s QoL following PICU discharge remains underexplored. Understanding this relationship could inform the development of targeted interventions to support families and improve long-term child well-being.

To address these gaps, this study examines the relationship between parental resilience and children’s QoL in a Thai tertiary care setting. By comparing outcomes between parents of children discharged from the PICU and those from general paediatric wards, this study aims to (1) evaluate group differences in parental resilience and perceived child QoL and (2) examine whether parental resilience predicts child QoL over time. We hypothesised that parents of PICU patients would demonstrate lower resilience and their children lower QoL at follow-up, and that parental resilience would significantly predict child QoL outcomes.

sec.title: Participants and procedures
sec.p: This prospective cohort study was conducted at Chiang Mai University Hospital, Thailand between February 2021 and August 2022. We enrolled parent–child dyads with children aged 4–16 years who were discharged from either PICU or general paediatric ward.

The required sample size was determined a priori to assess the correlation between parental resilience and child QoL. Based on a two-sided alpha of 0.05, power of 80%, and an expected correlation coefficient of 0.30, a minimum of 85 participants was required, as calculated using standard methods.23 To accommodate potential attrition, we aimed to recruit 100 parent–child dyads. A total of 95 participants completed both timepoints, providing sufficient power for the primary analysis.

Inclusion criteria were: (1) children aged 4–16 years discharged from either the PICU or general paediatric ward and (2) availability of a parent or primary caregiver who could complete the Thai-language questionnaires. Exclusion criteria included: (1) parent unable to complete the questionnaire due to language barrier, cognitive limitation or health condition; (2) parental refusal to participate and (3) parent or child death prior to enrolment.

Written informed consent was obtained from all participants. Demographic and clinical data were collected at enrolment through interviews and medical record review. Parent characteristics included age, gender, education level, marital status and family income. Child characteristics included age, gender, diagnosis, illness information and hospitalisation details. Parents completed questionnaires assessing their resilience and their child’s QoL at discharge (T1) and 2 months postdischarge (T2). The 2-month follow-up time point was chosen based on previous literature indicating this period as critical for initial adjustment and early identification of postintensive care psychological and functional impairments, allowing timely intervention.10 24 The study followed the STROBE (Strengthening the Reporting of Observational Studies in Epidemiology) guidelines for reporting cohort studies. Patients and members of the public were not involved in the design, conduct, reporting or dissemination of this research.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Parental resilience was measured using the Resilience Quotient questionnaire (RQ) developed by the Thai Department of Mental Health. The RQ consists of 20 questions categorised into 3 dimensions: emotional stability, willpower and problem-solving skills. Each item is rated on a 4-point Likert scale, with total scores ranging from 0 to 80. Higher scores indicate better resilience. The RQ has demonstrated good reliability with internal consistency (Cronbach’s α=0.749) and has been validated in Thai populations, showing strong construct validity in stress-related studies.25

Children’s health-related QoL was measured using the validated Thai version of the Paediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) 4.0 Generic Core Scales, parent-proxy version.26 27 This 23-item scale evaluates four domains: physical, emotional, social and school functioning. Responses are scored on a 5-point Likert scale and transformed to a 0–100 scale, with higher scores indicating better QoL. The instrument yields individual domain scores, a Physical Health Summary score (equivalent to the Physical Functioning domain), a Psychosocial Health Summary score (average of the emotional, social and school functioning domains), and a Total Scale score (average of all domains). The Generic Core Scales have demonstrated excellent reliability, with Cronbach’s alpha >0.90 for the Total Scale, and strong construct validity across diverse paediatric populations, including both healthy and chronically ill children.3 4 28 29 A decrease of 4.5 points or more on the PedsQL is regarded as the minimally clinically important difference (MCID), indicating a change likely to be perceived as detrimental by patients.30

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: No patients or members of the public were involved in the design, conduct, reporting or dissemination of this study

sec.title: Statistical methods
sec.p: Data were analysed using SPSS V.25.0 and R V.4.0.5. Complete case analysis was used for longitudinal analyses, including only participants with data at both time points (n=95), as the nature of the missing data (eg, deaths, loss to follow-up) was not assumed to be random. In this context, imputing outcomes could introduce bias by inaccurately estimating values for participants with systematically different outcomes.

Baseline characteristics were reported for all enrolled participants (n=100). Between-group comparisons used independent t-tests, while within-group changes were assessed using repeated measures models. Although some PedsQL scores exhibited slight skewness, parametric tests were applied based on the central limit theorem, sample size >30, and prior validation studies supporting their application in parametric statistical testing.28 Additionally, histograms and Shapiro-Wilk tests were used to assess normality, and all variables demonstrated acceptable approximation to normal distribution. Cross-Lagged Panel Analysis31 examined bidirectional relationships between parental resilience and child QoL. Hierarchical multiple regression identified predictors of child QoL at follow-up, with models incorporating demographic (model 1), clinical (model 2) and psychosocial factors (model 3) sequentially. This sequential approach allowed for assessment of the unique contribution of resilience after accounting for other factors. Variables were selected based on theoretical relevance and previous research.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Of 140 potential participants screened (82 from the PICU and 58 from the general ward), 100 parent–child dyads (58 PICU, 42 ward) were enrolled following eligibility assessment. A total of 40 were excluded: 36 due to language barriers, 3 due to parental refusal and 1 due to child death prior to enrolment.

Among those enrolled, 95 dyads (53 PICU, 42 ward) completed both assessments and were included in the final analysis. Five dyads from the PICU group were lost to follow-up: three due to child death and two due to loss of contact. This corresponded to a retention rate of 91.4% in the PICU group and 100% in the ward group, with an overall retention rate of 95%. All longitudinal analyses were conducted on the 95 participants with complete data at both time points. The participant flow is illustrated in online supplemental figure S1.

Retention strategies included scheduling follow-up assessments to coincide with routine paediatric clinical appointments, complemented by regular phone call reminders. These combined approaches facilitated participant convenience and contributed to our high retention rate (95%) at the 2-month postdischarge assessment.
The mean age of the children was 10.3±5.6 years, and 48% were male. PICU patients had significantly longer hospital stays compared with general ward patients (24.5 vs 7.7 days, p<0.001).

Among parent participants, the majority were mothers (93%), with a mean age of 37.8±6.9 years. Mothers of general ward patients had higher educational attainment than PICU mothers (52.4% vs 25.9% with college education or higher, p=0.007). Family income and baseline QoL scores were comparable between groups (18 922 vs 25 696 baht/month, p=0.130; 70.8 vs 64.6, p=0.096, respectively). sec.p: In the initial PICU group (n=58), 77.6% were emergency admissions. Most patients underwent invasive procedures (62.1%), including endotracheal intubation (46.6%) and central line insertion (44.8%). Lumbar puncture was performed in 3.4% of cases.

sec.title: Temporal changes in parental resilience and children’s QoL
sec.p: Initial parental resilience scores showed no significant difference between PICU and ward groups (63.7 vs 63.6, p=0.947). At the 2-month follow-up, both groups demonstrated improvement. Only the ward group demonstrated a statistically significant increase in resilience scores (p=0.001).

Both groups showed significant improvements in physical and emotional functioning on the PedsQL from baseline to follow-up (p<0.001 for both groups). However, the ward group demonstrated significantly superior improvements in social (21.8 vs 8.6 points, p=0.005), psychosocial functioning (8.4 vs 4.9 points, p=0.011), and total PedsQL scores (12.1 vs 4.1 points, p=0.038) (table 2). sec.title: Cross-lagged panel analysis
sec.p: The cross-lagged panel model revealed significant stability paths for both parental resilience and child QoL over time (figure 2). Parental resilience showed substantial temporal stability (β=0.443, SE=0.086, p<0.001), as did child QoL (β=0.560, SE=0.108, p<0.001). The cross-lagged analysis demonstrated a significant effect of initial parental resilience on subsequent child QoL (β=0.426, SE=0.206, p=0.038), while the reverse relationship—the effect of initial child QoL on subsequent parental resilience—was not significant (β=0.044, SE=0.045, p=0.330). The relationship between variables strengthened over time, with covariance increasing from baseline (estimate=5.342, SE=13.631, p=0.695) to follow-up (estimate=56.151, SE=13.329, p<0.001).

sec.title: Predictors of child QoL
sec.p: A hierarchical multiple regression analysis of all participants was conducted to examine predictors of child QoL (QoL) at follow-up (T2) across three models, including demographic (model 1), clinical (model 2) and psychosocial factors (model 3) (table 3). The model 1 explained 9.1% of the variance, maternal education was a significant predictor (β=0.993, p=0.049). The model 2 explained 13% of the variance, PICU length of stay had a small negative effect on child QoL (β=−1.025, p=0.046). PICU versus ward status also had a negative but non-significant impact (β=−1.780, p=0.056). The model 3 explained 45.7% of the variance, change in parental resilience (β=1.090, p<0.01) and baseline child QoL (β=0.524, p<0.01) were the most significant predictors of child QoL at follow-up. The baseline parental resilience was also significant (β=0.879, p<0.05).

sec.p: In the PICU-specific analysis (n=53) (online supplemental table S1), results indicate that the model 1 explained 7.8% of the variance, child age (β=0.891, p=0.005) was a significant positive predictor of child QoL. The model 2 explained 23% of the variance, with lumbar puncture showing a significant negative effect on child QoL (β=−33.701, p=0.045). The final model explained 68.5% of the variance, both change in parental resilience (β=1.686, p<0.01) and baseline child QoL (β=0.587, p<0.01) were the strongest predictors of child QoL at follow-up, with higher parental resilience and baseline QoL leading to better outcomes.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our findings demonstrate that parental resilience significantly predicts children’s QoL following intensive care discharge, with important implications for family-centred critical care. Three key patterns emerged: the temporal development of parental resilience, its unidirectional relationship with child QoL and the identification of modifiable factors affecting recovery.

Initial resilience scores were comparable between PICU and general ward parents, suggesting similar baseline psychological resources regardless of admission type. However, the trajectories diverged during follow-up, with general ward parents showing greater improvement in resilience scores. These results highlight the need for continued psychosocial support for all families, particularly in critical care settings. This finding aligns with previous research showing that PICU admission can have lasting psychological effects on parents, although most demonstrate recovery from post-traumatic stress within a year of discharge.19 32 33

Although statistically significant, the clinical significance of these differences warrants careful interpretation. Prior studies suggest that a change of approximately 4.5 points on the PedsQL is considered the MCID in paediatric populations.4 30 Accordingly, the 12.1-point improvement observed in the ward group and 4.1-point gain in the PICU group may represent clinically meaningful changes, though group differences at baseline complicate interpretation. For parental resilience, no established thresholds for clinically meaningful change exist, highlighting the need to establish MCID thresholds for resilience measures in caregiving contexts.

The cross-lagged panel analysis revealed a significant unidirectional relationship: initial parental resilience predicted subsequent child QoL, whereas the reverse pathway was not significant. This finding extends current understanding by demonstrating that parental psychological resources may serve as a crucial foundation for child recovery. The strengthening relationship between these factors over time suggests that early support for parental resilience could yield cascading benefits for child outcomes. This directional pattern aligns with findings from Long et al,34 who used cross-lagged modelling to demonstrate a unidirectional association from maternal PTSS to child PTSS, reinforcing the broader notion that caregiver functioning shapes child psychological outcomes across domains.

Notably, our hierarchical regression analyses identified parental resilience (both baseline and changes) as significant predictors of child QoL, even after controlling for demographic and clinical factors. This held true in both the full sample and PICU-specific analyses, indicating the robustness of this relationship. However, demographic and clinical factors, including PICU admission status and length of stay, were not significant predictors. This aligns with systematic review findings indicating that illness severity and hospital stay duration are not directly linked to parent and family outcomes.35 Instead, pre-existing family functioning and psychological resources, as well as postdischarge challenges, appear to play a more critical role in shaping child recovery.

The lower educational attainment among mothers in the PICU group may reflect heightened vulnerability and a greater need for clear communication, psychosocial support and accessible health information, all of which may influence resilience during and after hospitalisation.

Our findings point to practical strategies for improving outcomes in paediatric critical care. Early identification of parents needing support is crucial. Healthcare providers should consider implementing routine resilience screening at PICU admission, focusing particularly on families with risk factors such as emergency admissions or prolonged stays. This screening could be integrated into existing admission protocols, allowing for timely intervention. Support strategies might include regular psychological check-ins, structured emotional support sessions and clear communication about procedures and expected outcomes.

The transition from hospital to home represents a critical period for intervention. A comprehensive discharge plan should address both medical and psychological aspects of recovery. Follow-up care should extend beyond traditional medical monitoring to include assessment of family adaptation and continued access to support resources. Healthcare providers can facilitate this through scheduled follow-up calls, integration of resilience assessment in post-PICU clinic visits, and maintaining connections with community support services.

These recommendations should be tailored to local resources and cultural contexts. Even in resource-limited settings, basic screening and targeted support for high-risk families can be implemented through existing staff resources and community partnerships. The goal is to support parental resilience as a means of enhancing both parent and child outcomes following critical illness.

Although this study provides valuable insights into parental resilience and child QoL following PICU discharge, several limitations should be noted. First, while the overall sample size met the a priori target, subgroup analyses—particularly within the PICU cohort—may have been underpowered to detect small to moderate effects.

Second, the study assessed only short-term outcomes, which may not reflect the full trajectory of recovery for either parents or children. While the 2-month time frame enabled the observation of early adaptation, longer-term follow-up (eg, 6–12 months) would provide more comprehensive insights into the stability and durability of the relationship between parental resilience and child QoL. Moreover, as an observational study with only two time points, we cannot infer causal relationships, despite the directional patterns suggested by the cross-lagged analysis. Nor can we fully characterise recovery trajectories, which typically require at least three repeated measurements.

Third, both parental resilience and child QoL were reported by the same parent using self-report and proxy-report questionnaires, which may introduce shared method variance or reporter bias. The use of the parent-proxy version of the PedsQL, rather than direct child self-report, may particularly influence interpretation of psychosocial domains.

Fourth, although we adhered to standardised reporting guidelines, the absence of a prepublished protocol introduces the possibility of design or analytical bias. Fifth, the sample included children with a wide range of diagnoses and illness severities, potentially introducing unmeasured confounding variables that may have affected both parental resilience and child QoL.

Sixth, in the Thai cultural context, where maternal caregiving and family cohesion are highly emphasised, our findings may predominantly reflect maternal resilience. Paternal resilience may influence child outcomes through different mechanisms and deserves further investigation.

Finally, this was a single-centre study conducted in a tertiary care hospital in Thailand. The generalisability of our findings to other healthcare settings or cultural contexts may therefore be limited.

Future research should explore the development and evaluation of targeted interventions to support parental resilience during the PICU admission and postdischarge phases. Multicentre and cross-cultural studies could help distinguish universal vs context-specific mechanisms. In addition, future studies should make concerted efforts to recruit paternal participants and examine how maternal versus paternal resilience differentially contributes to child recovery trajectories.

While our findings suggest associations between parental resilience and child outcomes, intervention studies are needed to determine whether actively supporting parental resilience during hospitalisation improves child recovery. Such interventions might include psychological support resources, clear communication protocols and structured transition support from hospital to home. However, the development of such interventions should be informed by a nuanced understanding of the complex psychological, social and cultural factors that influence resilience.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study identified parental resilience as a key predictor of children’s recovery following intensive care admission. Our findings suggest that assessing and supporting parental psychological well-being may be an important component of comprehensive paediatric critical care, potentially contributing to improved recovery trajectories for both parents and children.
